snippet: Mr. Abe, who wants the military to take on limited combat roles, sees himself in the mold of his grandfather, who helped redefine cooperation with America.
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe faces growing protests as he seeks to reshape national identity by shedding long-held pacifism and allowing soldiers to be sent on overseas mission for first time since World War II; observers point to Abe's close identification with his late grandfather, former Prime Min Nobusuke Kishi, who extended country's military alliance with United States.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Abe, who wants the military to take on limited combat roles, sees himself in the mold of his grandfather, who helped redefine cooperation with America.

headline.main: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
headline.print_headline: An Effort to Redefine Japan Echoes a Family History
